subanswer.text: We can now apply the identity $\sqrt{a}+\sqrt{b} = 2\sqrt{a\cdot b} / (\sqrt{a}+\sqrt{b})$. In our case, $a = 2.5$ and $b = 0.7$, so we have $\sqrt{2.5}+\sqrt{0.7} = 2\sqrt{2.5\cdot 0.7}/(\sqrt{2.5}+\sqrt{0.7})$. Next, we simplify the denominator using the same identity: $\sqrt{2.5}+\sqrt{0.7}=\sqrt{2.5}(1+\sqrt{0.7}/\sqrt{2.5}) = \sqrt{2.5}(\sqrt{1}+(\sqrt{0.7}/\sqrt{2.5}))$. Squaring both sides yields $2.5+2\sqrt{2.5}\sqrt{0.7}+(\sqrt{0.7}/\sqrt{2.5})^2 = 2.5(1+2\sqrt{0.7/2.5}+\boxed{(\sqrt{0.7}/\sqrt{2.5})^2})$.
